comments.commentBody:
Whoops, I think Trump just shot himself in his foot.

His allegation amplifies the need for an independent investigation into Russia's involvement in the USA's election, Donald Trump's link with Russia and the response of the American government to these concerns.

How can Trump not demand an independent investigation of these concerns?
I agree. The media should just ignore him, just like the boy who cried wolf.
Next it will be another round of lock her up. Then if all else fails declare war on North Korea.

Where is the evidence that the Russians 'hacked' the 2016 election process?  The Times' obvious slant against Trump is becoming uglier every day.  PLEASE, if your reporters have 'facts'  -- publish them.  Otherwise -- shut up and get over the fact that Trump won.
Actually, his phones were not tapped.  His gold plated toilets were tapped, as the only honest thing that emerges from Trump is from that end of his anatomy.

If you actually read this paper and/or dozens of other credible news outlets, you might know there is plenty of evidence that Russia hacked, or at the very least, attempted to influence the outcome of the 2016 election.  Oops, sorry, guess you only get your news from Trump.  You are hereby pardoned.

I am confused by your confusion. In January President Trump was briefed by the Intelligence Agencies about the Russians hacking of the 2016 election process. The hacking led to sanctions being implemented by then President Obama. At that time President Elect Trump said, as reported on Fox News, "the Russians are up to some tricks". The imposed sanctions were supported by Congressional Republicans. Please do your own fact checking on this matter. There are volumes of evidence with regard to the hacking by the Russians in an effort to influence the elections...as I said, I am confused by your confusion.

Invalid reasoning, Mr. John. No one has to read between the lines of Trump's crazy tweet to know that Trump accuses President Obama of wiretapping. And he explodes win a flurry of twitter. His reactions are not within the realm of normal behavior—experts have discerned multiple disorders in the man. (By the way, that's wiretapp in Trumpese.) And if you don't find that pathologically lying president that is Trump accusing any former president, let alone one known for his integrity and rectitude, remarkable you might try reading up on presidential history.

This presidency reminds me of a very bad hire we experienced early in my career.
He was an Executive Director.

He exhausted us with his ineptitude, hired similarly unqualified staffers and had no respect of the enormity of the responsibilities of his department. He Eventuly dragged us into bankruptcy after a long and chaotic five year period.

Despite Trump's glaring ineptitude, Russia criminally stole information and disrupted our election to give us Trump. Trump continues to flail, surround himself with predominantly inept staffers, as he issues Executive orders on issues he knows NOTHING about.

I hope the press stops being hostage to the distraction antics of Trump regarding the alleged Russian WH control and other issues. It is NOT a light or partisan matter!

If our president is beholden to one of the most criminal and corrupt leaders in the world, Putin, the media is obligated to expose these facts and protect our democracy.
Hang in there, Doug.  You are appreciated, even if you don't hear it enough. I know I appreciate my ex's love & care, but too late for me.
Thank YOU for wishing her peace and not a medical miracle. The greatest gift.
My heart walked with yours while reading this beautiful piece.  Thank you for this gift.

My heart is with you. Thank you for sharing this personal and profound story.  You trusted him with the treasure of your heart and he cherished and valued that gift! Beautiful love story. When the time is right I hope to meet someone like your husband!
Lifelong Reader I'd say it's also from someone in denial, someone unable to let go.
Thank you, Amy, for your beautiful piece, which has inspired me to love those close to me more fervently. My thoughts are with you and your family today.

Amy, I do want to marry your husband (or someone very like him), because his description is illuminated by your love. You see him as he cannot see himself. And it occurs to me that we all need this gift: someone to describe us through the perspective of their love for us. How rare and precious this is, and bless you for showing us how.

I picked up a sweet and funny little book called "Duck Rabbit Duck" just because I liked the cover. My own son was much too old for it and there weren't any trains in it. But its wit and humor captivated me.
I read this article with a heart full of sweetness and sadness- you live on in your writing, and I thank you for sharing this with us. You are going to be the recipient of much love as you go onto the next journey. I add my own to you and your family.
Just beautiful and eloquent. I doubt, given the strength of the love that you share with your husband, that he will ever want to repeat it. God bless you and your family.
What about the fact that he is a lawyer?

I met my husband’s late wife a few years before she died but didn’t get to really know her until just a few months before her death at age 65 from cancer. After she died, I became friends with her widow. About a year and a half later, Gene and I fell in love. It’s been 7 years since Carol died and she is still in Gene’s heart. But he has a big heart with a lot of room for me as well. We have a wonderful relationship; both of us appreciate our time together. Gene knew what it took to make a good marriage work. It sounds like your husband does as well (though he is a far better cook than Gene!). Like your husband, Gene is a very good man. I am so glad he is not alone and I am grateful that I get to be the one to keep him company. I thought I would share our story with you as our relationship is something like the one you hope for your husband after you’re gone. But I’m sorry you’re going. I’m still sorry Carol had to go. It worked out well for me and, eventually, for Gene but it was a terrible price to pay. Thank you for the beautiful article.
You are an inspiration to all. Thank you for sharing your story ❤ Sending all my prayers to you and your family.

My husband had a wonderful first marriage until his wife of 24 years passed away. I never met his first wife, but by all accounts she was an amazing woman who loved him dearly and appreciated what a great man he is. Before she died, she asked her friends to find him a worthy wife. One of them had known me for many years, and several years later when I got divorced she told me she knew the perfect guy for me. She was right: he's sweet, nerdy, curious and energetic. I am sad for the loss that he and his family and friends experienced when his first wife died. I try to honor her in all that I do, and appreciate every moment with this fantastic man. Thank you for the love and courage you've shown by writing this essay. You are truly a great woman with a heart full of love.
You missed her mentioning about his Law Practice?

Amy, thanks to you and your lovely, touching and heartfelt article, I am in love with your husband, but even more in love with you.

And, I can and do relate from first hand experience, I am sad to say.
Thank your for this achingly beautiful essay. I wish you, your husband, and your family grace and peace.
Nice one Jase.
Your words are beautiful and I wish you a miracle so you have more time with what seems to be an amazing life lived with love.

I couldn't stop sobbing after reading this. I worked with Jason Rosenthal, the writer of this article's husband, and he is an amazing person and is so deeply in love with his wife. Every time he would leave the office he would say "I'm leaving now I'm going home to my bride" still after 18 years of marriage at the time. My heart goes out to them.
